Award.AwardTitle: HumanConnect: Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This scholars program at the Ohio State University offers talented students the opportunity to live and study in a community as they participate in career-themed activities and take advantage of carefully-architected support structures. Scholars have specialized advising, attend first year classes together as a cohort and have a host of thematically related activities available that contribute to their success as students and in securing employment. These scholars are selected because of their desire to utilize engineering talent for the betterment of marginalized peoples and underserved communities. Using engineering to obtain direct positive effects on humanity is often called "humanitarian engineering" and this humanitarian engineering program is enrolling 144 scholars. The program has two primary goals: 1) Positively impact retention and graduation rate of engineering students with financial need and 2) Improve academic performance relative to a control group. The program is sustainable in that it will not create new programs, curricula or degree requirements; its financial support will facilitate degree completion and career placement for a group of students who have financial need and are academically talented. The project has three secondary goals 3) Incorporate humanitarian engineering ideas more broadly across campus, 4) Increase diversity, and 5) Develop well-rounded engineers and problem-solvers who are able to think globally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The HumanConnect scholarship program under NSF S-STEM benefitted undergraduate engineering students in the Humanitarian Engineering Scholars Program at the Ohio State University who had financial need and were deemed to be ?academically qualified?. The program impacted a total of 27 students in two cohorts who maintained eligibility, starting autumn 2013 and 2014 and renewed through to graduation for up to a full 4 years. Each autumn, the scholarship amounts, nominally $3750 - $5000, were adjusted to relative to one another to align with the students? unmet financial need in light of the total cost of attendance.

The HumanConnect program had two primary goals (Intellectual Merit): 1) Positively impact retention and graduation rate of engineering students with financial need and 2) Improve academic performance relative to a control group. With respect to the first goal, data show that, for those students who maintained eligibility, 100% from Cohort 1 graduated within the six years which passed since the beginning of the program, and 92.9% of the students from Cohort 2 graduated within the five years which elapsed. These rates far exceed the graduation rates for the College of Engineering as a whole. The students in the program also had better graduation rates than those in the control group (six year = 80% and 5 year = 53%). The control group consisted of students with similar financial need from another engineering scholars community. With respect to the second goal, students in the program earned consistently higher cumulative GPAs than the students in the control group (3.352 vs 3.126).

A secondary (Broader Impact) Goal for the program was to ?Develop well-rounded engineers and problem-solvers who are able to think globally?.

In evaluating this goal, we collected data on participation in co-op education. More students in the program (36.7% or 0.53 semesters per student) participated in co-ops during their academic programs than the control group (17.4% or 0.35 semesters per student).

We surmised that, in general, students with a scholarship feel a greater sense of financial security than students with the same level of financial need without a scholarship. This security leads them to consider taking part in programs or activities (like co-op, study abroad, etc..) that are considered valuable and formative, but may push out graduation. Students with substantial financial obligation (who are often incurring significant debt) tend to focus more narrowly on their education and shortest time to degree completion and thus and thus participate in fewer co-curricular activities.

In year 5 of the award, the evaluation process included qualitative interviews with students in the program, including several who had already graduated. Participants described how the HumanConnect award relieved financial burdens, removed financial stressors, facilitated a greater degree of involvement, allowed them to focus more on academics, and reduced their need to hold part-time jobs during the academic year. Some students worked only for extra spending money or experience. All of the participants reported being comfortable with their current financial position in terms of loan debt and future prospects.
